definitions.definition: To include so that it no longer has separate existence; to overwhelm ; to cause to disappear as if by swallowing up; to incorporate ; to assimilate ; to take in and use up .
To engulf, as in water; to swallow up .
definitions.dating_raw: Attested from the late 15th century until the late 18th century.

definitions.definition: To suck up ; to drink in ; to imbibe , like a sponge or as the lacteals of the body; to chemically take in.
definitions.dating_raw: first attested in the early 17th century.

definitions.definition: To be absorbed, or sucked in; to sink in .
examples: The drops of water slowly absorbed into the dry sponge.

definitions.definition: To take in energy and convert it.
examples: Heat, light, and electricity are absorbed in the substances into which they pass.

subdefinitions.definition: in receiving a physical impact or vibration without recoil.
in receiving sound energy without repercussion or echo.
taking in radiant energy and converting it to a different form of energy, like heat.

definitions.dating_raw: first attested in the early 18th century.

definitions.definition: To engross or engage wholly; to occupy fully.
definitions.dating_raw: first attested in the late 18th century.
first attested in the mid 19th century.

examples: If we fail to absorb the lessons of history, we are doomed to repeat them.
definitions.dating_raw: first attested in the late 19th century.

definitions.definition: To assume or pay for as part of a commercial transaction .

examples: I’ll absorb the charge for the window replacement.

definitions.definition: To accept or purchase in quantity.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To include so that it no longer has separate existence; to overwhelm ; to cause to disappear as if by swallowing up; to incorporate ; to assimilate ; to take in and use up . [first attested c. 1350 to 1470.]
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , obsolete ) To engulf, as in water; to swallow up . [Attested from the late 15th century until the late 18th century.]
( transitive ) To suck up ; to drink in ; to imbibe , like a sponge or as the lacteals of the body; to chemically take in. [first attested in the early 17th century.]
( intransitive ) To be absorbed, or sucked in; to sink in .
( transitive , physics , chemistry ) To take in energy and convert it. [first attested in the early 18th century.]
( transitive ) To engross or engage wholly; to occupy fully. [first attested in the late 18th century.]
( transitive ) To occupy or consume time. [first attested in the mid 19th century.]
( transitive ) To assimilate mentally. [first attested in the late 19th century.]
( transitive , business ) To assume or pay for as part of a commercial transaction .
( transitive ) To accept or purchase in quantity.
